item.title: European Allies Wary of Buying American as They Plan Defense Buildup
item.description: For European countries that just approved the biggest increase in military spending in decades, “Buy American” is looking a lot less appealing than it once was. They may have no choice.
item.dc:creator: Natalia Drozdiak, Andrea Palasciano

media:content.media:description: Patriot surface-to-air missile systems at Warsaw Babice Airport. Photographer: Janek Skarzynski/AFP

item.title: India Presses China to Demarcate Disputed Himalayan Border
item.description: India’s defense minister Rajnath Singh pressed his Chinese counterpart to move forward on demarcating the disputed Himalayan frontier, in a bid to ease border tensions and strengthen ties between the world’s two most populous nations.
item.dc:creator: Sudhi Ranjan Sen

media:content.media:description: An Indian army convoy drives towards Leh, bordering China in Gagangir, India. Photographer: Yawar Nazir/Getty Images

item.title: Philippine Prosecutors Push for Sara Duterte Trial, Ouster
item.description: Prosecutors at the Philippines’ House of Representatives have asked the Senate to proceed with the trial of impeached Vice President Sara Duterte, saying she should be convicted and barred from politics.
item.dc:creator: Cliff Harvey Venzon

media:content.media:description: Sara Duterte, Philippines' vice president, during a news conference in Mandaluyong, Metro Manila, the Philippines, on Friday, Feb. 7, 2025. Duterte said her lawyers are preparing to fight the impeachment case, signaling she’s ready to defend herself as her feud with President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. intensifies.

item.title: Russia Sharply Boosted Drone Output in May, Think Tank Reports
item.description: Russia increased combat drone production by almost 17% in May, a think tank reported, sharply accelerating output as President Vladimir Putin continued to reject calls for a ceasefire in his war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Sofia Sorochinskaia

media:content.media:description: Emergency services at a site following a Russian drone and missile attack, in Kyiv, on June 23.

item.title: Tusk Says Ballot Recount Unlikely to Reverse Presidential Result
item.description: Polish Prime Minister Donald Tusk said suspected voting irregularities in the country’s June 1 presidential election were unlikely to lead to a reversal of the victory of nationalist Karol Nawrocki.
item.dc:creator: Agnieszka Barteczko

media:content.media:description: Rafal Trzaskowski, Mayor of Warsaw and candidate for President of Poland, center, and Donald Tusk, Poland's prime minister, right, march with supporters in the Great Patriots March along Marszalkowska Street in Warsaw, Poland, on Sunday, May 25, 2025. The slump in Polish stocks, one of the year’s global equity standouts, signals that traders are increasingly jittery about any more political surprises.

item.title: Trump Looks to Africa Next for Diplomatic Win
item.description: Rwanda and Congo are due to sign an accord in Washington, paving the way for US investment.
item.dc:creator: Michael J Kavanagh

media:content.media:description: An M23 soldier watches over a group of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda and Wazalendo and Armed Forces of the Democratic Republic of the Congo fighters in Goma, Democratic Republic of the Congo, on May 10. Photographer: Jospin Mwisha/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: German Coalition Risks Conflict Over Contentious Minimum Wage
item.description: An independent commission agreed Germany’s statutory minimum wage should be increased in two steps to €14.60 ($17.11) in 2027, in a move that could stoke discord in Chancellor Friedrich Merz’s ruling coalition.
item.dc:creator: Kamil Kowalcze

media:content.media:description: Commuters at Berlin Central Station.

item.title: Cambodia’s Hun Sen Urges Change in Thai Leadership Over Border Dispute
item.description: Cambodia’s most influential politician called for a leadership change in Thailand, citing doubts about the prime minister’s ability to manage a border dispute between the two countries.
item.dc:creator: Philip Heijmans

media:content.media:description: Hun Sen

item.title: China’s Top Diplomat to Visit Europe as Tensions With US Linger
item.description: Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi is set to visit Europe next week, a trip that comes as Beijing tries to counter US tariff pressure by improving ties with other trading partners.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Wong

media:content.media:description: China's Foreign Minister Wang Yi Photographer: Jessica Lee/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Lots More on What's Going On in Iran's Markets
item.description: There's major geopolitical risk.
item.dc:creator: Tracy Alloway, Joe Weisenthal

media:content.media:description: Iranian men monitor the stock market at the stock exchange in Tehran.

item.title: Lots More on What’s Going On in Iran’s Markets (Podcast)
item.description: Iran is a huge country with a sizable stock market. And yet, years of sanctions and other restrictions mean it’s tough to even look up its stock prices (much less invest there.) In this episode, we catch up with Maciej Wojtal, CEO and CIO of AmtelonCapital, an Amsterdam-based fund that specializes in Iranian stocks. We talk about what the past week has been like for the market, what he’s hearing from people on the ground in Tehran, plus disruptions to businesses and oil. We talk about how Irania
item.dc:creator: Tracy Alloway, Joe Weisenthal

item.title: Starmer’s Latest U-Turn Risks £3 Billion Hit and More Tax Rises
item.description: Keir Starmer backed down to a rebellion within his own Labour party over a planned £5 billion ($6.9 billion) cut to disability entitlements, in a costly U-Turn that dents his authority and leaves his chancellor struggling to avoid tax hikes.
item.dc:creator: Irina Anghel, Alex Wickham, Ailbhe Rea

media:content.media:description: Keir Starmer attends the British Chambers of Commerce conference in London on June 26.

item.title: Iran Dismisses US Claim of Nuclear Talks Resuming Next Week
item.description: Iran denied that nuclear talks with the US are scheduled to resume, diminishing prospects for diplomacy after President Donald Trump suggested a deal could come as early as next week.
item.dc:creator: Eltaf Najafizada, Patrick Sykes

media:content.media:description: Iran’s foreign minister Abbas Araghchi Photographer: Fred Merz/Bloomberg

item.title: China Ousts Top General from Elite Military Body as Purge Grows
item.description: China has removed a top general from the nation’s apex military body led by President Xi Jinping, as the defense establishment is facing a wave of purges.
item.dc:creator: Josh Xiao

media:content.media:description: Miao Hua Photographer: Kim Won Jin/Getty Images

item.title: Tina Brown: ‘I’m Concerned About American Women’
item.description: The onetime Vanity Fair editor and Substack convert talks to Mishal Husain about the current moment in US politics, and what’s next for media.
item.dc:creator: Mishal Husain

item.title: Lutnick Says US-China Trade Truce Signed, 10 Deals Imminent
item.description: The US and China finalized a trade understanding reached last month in Geneva, US Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick said, adding that the White House has imminent plans to reach agreements with a set of 10 major trading partners.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer A Dlouhy, Kailey Leinz, Joe Mathieu

media:content.media:description: Howard Lutnick Photographer: Allison Robbert/Bloomberg

item.title: Ramaphosa Accused of ‘Double Standard’ by Key Coalition Partner
item.description: South African President Cyril Ramaphosa fired a deputy minister from the second-largest party in the ruling coalition on Thursday, a move that renews strain on the stability of his administration.
item.dc:creator: S'thembile Cele, Paul Vecchiatto

media:content.media:description: Cyril Ramaphosa

item.title: Trump Teases ‘Big’ India Trade Deal as Negotiators Harden Stance
item.description: US President Donald Trump said a “very big” trade deal could be signed soon that would open up the Indian market to American business, as negotiators meet in Washington to break a recent deadlock over key issues.
item.dc:creator: Shruti Srivastava

media:content.media:description: Operations at the Jawaharlal Nehru Port in Navi Mumbai, India.

item.title: Lee Starts Term With 64% Rating on South Korea Recovery Optimism
item.description: South Korea’s new President Lee Jae Myung started his presidency with a higher approval rating than recent predecessors, as hopes for an economic recovery rise after months of political turbulence.
item.dc:creator: Soo-Hyang Choi

media:content.media:description: Lee Jae Myung shakes hands with lawmakers at the National Assembly in Seoul on June 26. Photographer: SeongJoon Cho/Bloomberg

item.title: Ireland’s Firms Brace for Economic Hit With Quiet Confidence
item.description: Hundreds of companies, 200,000 jobs, billions of euro in corporation tax revenue. Add it all up and Ireland’s reliance on US investment for its economic success is starkly clear.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Duggan

media:content.media:description: Paschal Donohoe at the Future of Finance in Dublin. Photographer: Dean O'Brien/Bloomberg

item.title: Thai Finance Chief to Visit US for Trade Talks, Denying 18% Levy
item.description: Thai Finance Minister Pichai Chunhavajira will visit the US next week for tariff negotiations in an attempt to clinch a trade deal ahead of Washington’s deadline on July 9.
item.dc:creator: Pathom Sangwongwanich

media:content.media:description: Pichai Chunhavajira Photographer: Valeria Mongelli/Bloomberg

item.title: Australian Treasurer Sues Foreign Investor in Rare Earths Miner
item.description: Australian Treasurer Jim Chalmers has started the first legal case in the Federal Court for an alleged breach of the nation’s foreign investment laws, saying a shareholder in a rare earths company failed to heed his order to sell its stake.
item.dc:creator: Paul-Alain Hunt

media:content.media:description: Jim Chalmers

item.title: House Plans Single Vote to Move Genius and Clarity Crypto Bills
item.description: House Republicans aim to get the Senate’s landmark stablecoin legislation — known as the Genius Act — to President Donald Trump’s desk for signature as soon as the week of July 7, according to people with direct knowledge of the strategy.
item.dc:creator: Lydia Beyoud, Yash Roy, Steven T. Dennis

media:content.media:description: The US Capitol. Photographer: Eric Lee/Bloomberg

item.title: South Korea Weighing US Request to Boost Defense Spending
item.description: South Korea is in talks with the US about raising its defense spending, a key demand of President Donald Trump as he calls on allies to ramp up their outlays on security and lessen the burden on the US.
item.dc:creator: Hyonhee Shin, Soo-Hyang Choi

media:content.media:description: A South Korea Army K1A1 tank fires during a joint live-fire exercise with the US Army in Pocheon, South Korea, in February.

item.title: Miami Defies DeSantis by Delaying Mayoral Election a Year
item.description: Miami’s city commission voted to postpone municipal elections set for November, giving the mayor and two commissioners another year in office in defiance of Governor Ron DeSantis.
item.dc:creator: Anna J Kaiser

media:content.media:description: Francis Suarez, mayor of Miami, speaks during at an event for Universa Investments in Miami, Florida, US, on Monday, Jan. 29, 2024.

item.title: Cuomo Won’t Quit NYC Mayor’s Race Before Friday Ballot Deadline
item.description: Andrew Cuomo has no plans to drop out of the New York City mayor’s race by a Friday deadline, according to a person familiar with the matter, meaning that his name will appear on the ballot in November as an independent.
item.dc:creator: Laura Nahmias

media:content.media:description: Workers dismantle the stage following New York City mayoral candidate Andrew Cuomo's election-night watch party in New York, on June 24,

item.title: Sanchez Suffers Jibes From EU Leaders Who Won’t Forget NATO Yet
item.description: Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez is hunkering down and trying to ignore the shade coming his way for refusing to sign up to new NATO spending targets demanded by Donald Trump.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Basteiro

media:content.media:description: Pedro Sanchez speaks to the press during the NATO summit in The Hague, on June 25.

item.title: Macron Says US Strikes on Iran’s Nuclear Program Were Effective
item.description: French President Emmanuel Macron said the US attacks on Iran’s nuclear facilities had been effective.
item.dc:creator: Samy Adghirni

media:content.media:description: The Isfahan Nuclear Technology and Research Center after US strikes, on June 22. Source: Satellite image ©2025 Maxar Technologies

item.title: As Hurricane Season Picks Up, Key Forecasting Tool Access Set to End
item.description: The US Navy will no longer distribute certain satellite readings, a move that will leave forecasters without important insights into storms’ strength and structure.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Rosenthal, Brian K Sullivan

media:content.media:description: A satellite image shows Hurricane Helene in the Gulf of Mexico moving towards Florida, on Sept. 26 2024.

item.title: Trump’s Iran Oil Comments Strain His ‘Maximum Pressure’ Policy
item.description: President Donald Trump indicated that he might be preparing to ease his “maximum pressure” campaign against Iran, potentially undercutting a central policy dating to his first term and provoking consternation among foreign policy hawks who argue that now is the time to escalate — not lessen — pressure on Tehran.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Chua

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump, during a news conference at the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) summit in The Hague, Netherlands, on Wednesday, June 25, 2025.
